comment._content: rjones0856, swanq, artolog and lazygardens: Thank you for your research on these images of Chinatown in New York City. As rjones0856 states, the Church of the Transfiguration, appears in the background and is still located today at 25 Mott Street. The Port Arthur restaurant was at 7-9 Mott Street as shown in this old postcard: www.cardcow.com/311741/port-arthur-restaurant-7-9-mott-st... I think therefore that the shooting in the caption may refer to one which happened on Mott Street, rather than the one referred to in the New York Times article sent by lazygardens, which happened on Pell Street. A July 1910 shooting in the same block of Mott Street as shown in the Bain images is detailed in this New York Times article which also mentions the Port Arthur restaurant and the Church of the Transfiguration: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F70611FD395D11738... However, probably more than one shooting occurred on Mott Street, so I don’t think we can pin it down to this one, given the lack of information in the Bain caption. But we can add some more details about the location of these two images in our description. Thanks for your help!

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Looking for something more in the presumed date range of the picture, there was the planned execution of Eng Hing and Lee Dock of the Hop Sing tong who had been convicted of the February 12, 1912 murder of Lee Kay (nephew of the head of the On Leong tong) at 18 Mott Street, in revenge for a Hop Sing murder. They were scheduled for Sing Sing's electric chair on December 11, 1914 and there was a reprieve until February 5th, 1915. Fearing more shooting, there was a large police presence in Chinatown around the time of the re-scheduled execution. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30813F93E5C1373... select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10B11F73F5A1573...
